column2: The Inspector Becomes The Inspected
What you'll do
Ada shows you some more cool tricks for the Inspector! (Part 2)
Hello again, {{user_name}}. Ready to do some more webpage hacking with the Inspector?
Let's dive right in - I'll launch your browser, just point it to https://hack-computer.com/about then open that Inspector gadget (Ctrl + Shift + I).
Here we are again! Activate the Select Element button in the top left corner of the Inspector. Remember, it looks like an arrow pointing at a box.

Click on any of the images in the page, and notice that the Inspector will highlight the line that adds that image to the page. It should start with <img... and then at some point later in the tag, it should have src="..." - you can read that as "source".
Let's replace that image. To do that, we need to change the address inside the src="..." part of the tag to a different 'source' address.

In the Inspector, double-click on the src text - be careful not to click the link to the actual image. Hit delete to erase the text, and then replace it with http://bit.ly/happycat1 (Press Enter when you're done).
Perfect. Hey, Felix, come check out what {{user_name}} just did!
Prrrowrrr, nyan! <Felix looks pleased.>
I knew he'd like it. The approval of a cat is always a good thing to have.

Let's try something you might already know, but from a different angle. Use the Element Selector to select “We're teaching a mindset." (The popup over the text when you mouse over it should say span). How you could make that text orange? If you have an idea, give it a try!
Here's how I'd do it - Once you've selected that text using the Element Selector, look in the Inspector pane, at the highlighted text.
I definitely recognize some of the code in there, style=... should look famillar. Let's change the color to color:orange;.
What you're doing is changing the page code behind the scenes - you're rewriting the webpage on the fly! Try changing that color to a hex color, like #76EECF.
Nice work! You can do that with text in any webpage - Who knows, maybe someone hid some text by making it the same color as the background.
Next, let’s try hacking a link. Try finding a link using the Element Selector. Remember, a link can be attached to text, buttons, images, videos, almost anything.
If you're having trouble finding a link, try selecting the "Get Now" button (not the text in the button, the button itself).

When you've found a link and selected it with the Element Selector, the Inspector should highlight some code that starts with <a... What we want is the href="..." part of the tag, which controls where the link goes.
When you've found it, double-click on href, delete the text in between the quotes, and replace it with http://www.nyan.cat
OK, now you can close the Inspector. Let's test your hacked link, by clicking the Get Now button.
See, Felix? I told you that {{user_name}} knew what you liked!
Brbrbrbr... <Felix puffs himself up and purrs quietly.>
Well, looks like you scored 10/10 in Felix's book! I'd say that's a purrrfect score. ::>^_^<:: See you later!
